data.title: Best hotels in Prague
data.meta_description: Read our expert reviews of hotels in Prague. Browse and book the best accommodation in Prague, based on location, style, facilities, rooms and dining.
data.text:
9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

A sweet treat of a hotel set in Prague's lovely old ‘Sugar Palace’. Between its outstanding modern Czech bistro and gorgeous bedrooms that highlight the building's tall windows and high ceilings, this is by far the best Andaz property in Europe and rises high above many of Prague’s classic five-star options. Read expert review

From

£ 416

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This elegant belle epoque hotel, set inside a 19th-century villa in the leafy district of Vinohrady, offers refined and stylish rooms and public areas. In addition, guests can find an equally handsome restaurant and lobby bar, plus a wellness area with a good menu of treatments. Read expert review

From

£ 183

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Prague’s Mama Shelter is located inside a former luxury communist hotel in Holešovice. It offers unusually spacious dimensions and interesting history alongside the brand’s usual riot of vibrant, whimsical décor and on-site amenities and activities. Service is welcoming and the local area up-and-coming. Read expert review

From

£ 61

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

With just 19 romantic rooms, the Golden Well (U Zlaté Studné) is an intimate and refined option for a memorable stay in Prague. The interior is sophisticated, there's a seriously top-notch restaurant with stellar views over the city, and service is pristine and personal throughout. Read expert review

From

£ 219

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This intimate hotel offers seven sumptuous rooms and luxurious suites in a great location right below Prague Castle. The richly restored historic interior has refined public spaces plus a gym and sauna area, and service is highly personalised throughout. Read expert review

From

£ 340

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

One of the finest Art Nouveau gems in a city more or less brimming with them, the Alcron is not just pretty to look at - inside and out - but has an impressive suite of amenities too. There’s an excellent restaurant, a very pleasant bar and a health area that’s open around the clock. Read expert review

From

£ 176

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Arguably one of Prague's most impressive accommodation options, the five-star Augustine merges a historical location with some seriously sharp contemporary design. Amenities include a comprehensive spa, a magnificent cocktail bar and courtyard restaurant with terrace. Read expert review

From

£ 346

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Positioned somewhere between a backpacker and a design hotel, this hip and multi-faceted hotel complex – part of the Leonardo Hotels portfolio – close to Wenceslas Square features a range of individually decorated rooms, a revolving bar, several in-house eateries, and a games room with in-built Skype booth. Read expert review

From

£ 121

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Inside an ensemble of historic bourgeois houses once connected by stone-walled underground passages, this five-star is the largest and most refined of the three Alchymist properties in the city. As well as an upscale restaurant, in-house chocolatier and basement spa, it offers top-notch service from youthful staff. Read expert review

From

£ 256

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Opened by the Art Deco Imperial hotel across the road - the intimate and upscale Cosmopolitan is every bit as sophisticated as its sister venue. Its distinguished interior hosts a top-end restaurant helmed by a celebrity chef, elegant and comfortable rooms, and a fitness area with a sauna. Read expert review

From

£ 144

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

With its opulent public spaces and exquisitely designed rooms, Carlo IV oozes Italian-style panache. With in-house facilities including a Roman spa with pool, a small but classy bar, a cigar bar set in one of the oldest cognac vaults in Europe and a couple of great restaurants, you'll feel like royalty. Read expert review

From

£ 190

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Prague's Four Seasons is one of the city's plushest and best-located hotels, with a blend of styles from different eras which lend plenty of character to the interior and rooms. Décor and furnishings are a mix of classic and contemporary, service is impeccable throughout and there's a swish spa and relaxation pool. Read expert review

From

£ 703

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This discreet luxury bolthole, tucked away in Prague's charming Mala Strana district, offers elegant serenity across several historic buildings. As well as sumptuous, spacious rooms and impeccable service, guests get access to top-quality Asian food at Spices, and a range of high-end treatments at the fantastic spa. Read expert review

From

£ 435

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This opulent and flamboyant boutique offers a music-themed experience, right down to a staff musicologist, a music library, and bedrooms dedicated to musicians. The interior is rich and glamorous, and there are Baroque gardens to enjoy, as well as efficient service and contemporary touches like iPads. Read expert review

From

£ 272

pn

9 /10 Telegraph expert rating

Located on a quiet street close to Prague's Old Town Square, this classy 59-room design hotel is nothing if not comprehensive. As well as slick, contemporary bedrooms dotted with punchy artworks, you'll find a rooftop spa and gym, a guest lounge with a daily happy hour, and one of the city's best steakhouses. Read expert review

From

£ 258

per person

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

The Hotel KING DAVID is a five-star kosher "Le Mehadrin" hotel. Supervised by Rabbi Eliyahu Rotenberg from Jerusalem and the Rabbinat kashrut department of the Jewish community in Prague, it has 67 plush guestrooms, a spa with a mikvah and a restaurant that serves specially prepared kosher meals. Read expert review

From

£ 128

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This is one of the city's grand dames. Bruce Willis, R.E.M, Princess Caroline of Monaco and David Bowie are just some of the luminaries to have stayed here. Though its glamour has faded a little over the years, recent refurbishments have created a wonderful new spa area and high-end restaurant. Read expert review

From

£ 81

per person

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This slick and functional hotel has a wonderful location just a few steps from the Old Town Square. Rooms are welcoming and comfortable, there’s onsite dining (and a bar), and staff are consistently helpful and friendly. Read expert review

From

£ 98

pn

8 /10 Telegraph expert rating

This historic inn offers 12 rooms in one venue and 16 in another annex over the road. Both are in the shadow of Charles Bridge's Gothic tower on the Mala Strana side, and are steeped in tradition with refined, wood-heavy interiors and fine fabrics and furnishings. There's a fine dining restaurant and a creperie too. Read expert review

From

£ 101

pn
